Incident.Summary: CHECK THE WELFARE RESULTING IN DUI ARREST

IncidentSuppNarrative.NarrativeText: ****L-43 EQUIPPED WITH AUDIO/VIDEO EQUIPMENT**** ****INCIDENT CAPTURED ON MVR BODYCAM**** ****TRAINING CERTIFICATIONS**** - Trained in administering Standardized Field Sobriety tests through the Maryland State Police and National Highway Traffic Safety Administration - Attended and graduated the University of Marylands DUI Institute - Trained and certified to operate RADAR and LIDAR through the Maryland State Police - Certified SFST Instructor through the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration - Trained in administering ARIDE tests through the Maryland State Police ****NARRATIVE**** On 10/28/2023, at approximately 0440hrs, I was dispatched to Northbound I-495 in the area of Route 414 for a vehicle stopped in the roadway. The caller advised a black vehicle was swerving back and forth and stopping in the roadway. I passed the vehicle as I was headed Southbound on I-495 and observed it to be stopped in lane 3 on Northbound I-495 at Route 414. By the time I got turned around and on scene, another trooper had moved the vehicle to the right shoulder. EMS was evaluating the driver in the ambulance as he had been passed out behind the wheel. The vehicle was a black Dodge Challenger (VA TRJ8919). I approached driver who had just exited the ambulance. I immediately detected the strong odor of an alcoholic beverage emanating from the drivers breath and person. The drivers movements were lethargic and uncoordinated. The drivers eyes were bloodshot and watery and his speech slurred and low volume. I identified the driver via his Florida ID card (FL H630112854280), as Calvin Lavon Hart (DOB 11/28/1985). I asked Hart why he had stopped in the road and he advised he had gotten tired. When asked how much alcohol he had consumed, Hart advised not that much. I asked Hart if he would be willing to participate in Standardized Field Sobriety Testing and he agreed. Hart stated he did not have any injuries or conditions that would deter him from completing any tests. I explained and then demonstrated each of the tests to Hart before he began. Hart did not have any questions about any of the tests and he advised that he understood all of the instructions given. The ground used was the asphalt surface of the roadway in front of Harts vehicle, which was reasonably level and reasonably free from debris. Before beginning the tests, I ensured all emergency vehicles on scene had their front emergency lights turned off. I continued to smell the strong odor of an alcoholic beverage emanating from Harts breath and person throughout testing. Horizontal Gaze Nystagmus 6 of 6 clues Harts eyes were bloodshot and watery. Both eyes tracked equally and both pupils were equally sized. I did not observe any resting Nystagmus in either eye. Hart exhibited the following clues: - Lack of smooth pursuit in both eyes - Distinct and sustained nystagmus at maximum deviation in both eyes - Onset of nystagmus prior to 45 degrees in both eyes Walk and Turn 7 of 8 clues - Starts too soon - Lost balance during instructional phase - Stepped off line multiple times - Missed heel to toe multiple times - Stopped walking after turn to ask for instructions. - Took 10 steps instead of 9 on both sets - Improper turn, spun on heel, turned in wrong direction Misc. Almost fell after completing the test, nearly stumbling into traffic. One Leg Stand 3 of 4 clues - Swayed while balancing - Put foot down multiple times - Used arms for balance multiple times Hart was arrested at 0513 hrs on 10/28/2023 and transported to MSP Forestville for processing. Once at MSP Forestville, Hart elected to listen to an English audio recording of the DR15. Hart was given a blank copy of the DR15 form to follow along. Once Hart was finished listening to the DR15 he advised that he did not want to take the intoximeter breath test. Hart signed the DR15 at 0538hrs on 10/28/2023. Hart was provided with a copy of the DR15 and DR15a. Sgt Estrin #6052, a certified Intoximeter Breath Tech was on-duty and available had Hart elected to take the Intoximeter Breath Test. Hart was cited the appropriate citations. Hart was released from MSP Forestville to a sober driver shortly after processing was complete.
